I had thought that UK inflation had a 25% chance of being over 2% and that UK GDP had a 5% chance of being over 2.5%, but the latest figures show that GDP growth that early in 2016 was increasing quarter by quarter is no longer doing so. It appears that the drop in the price of the pound has not stimulated industrial output (not a surprise to most economists who had already noted that in an economy like the UK's. changes in exchange rates no longer have a very great effect on output figures for manufactured goods. In the UK's case lack of available capacity and disinclination to invest in increasing it due to economic uncertainty is only being partly offset by increases in service activity. Larger inflation increases due to the fall in the pound are forecast. I had thought the effects might reach the 2% by the end of 2016, but it now looks more likely that the 2% figure will not show up until Q1 or even Q2 2017 (an annual rate of  1.7% for 2016 now seems more likely).

Let's see:
1.From a probabilistic point of view, you need to be right only 1/14 times, so the odds are not too shabby. Given the economic and political turmoil in Continental Europe and the UK, we can simply ignore them from the analysis.
2. No significant surge in commodities is expected for this period of time and the GDP of Canada has disappointed so far this year. Furthermore, inflation is safely below 2% currently.
3. The GDP growth of US is the wild card, but given the first 2 quarters' disappointing numbers, in spite of solid domestic consumption, I am doubtful that the events in Europe will drive enough money into the States so that it makes up in the last half of the year. A big fat 0 from me.

The setup of the question would favour a "Yes", since only one of 14 indicators needs to be over the threshold. The European countries and Japan can be comfortably eliminated, as will the UK due to the Brexit fallout. Hence the focus is on North America. The IMF forecasts do not indicate that the thresholds will be crossed and economic forecasts tend to be over-optimistic. The US GDP was weak in the first half of 2016, so even a late surge will not likely lift it over 2%. The Canadian economy looks stable, but is also negatively affected by low oil prices.

We're only looking for 1 event amongst 14 variables for this event to occur.  So even with a 10% chance individually (if uncorrelated) the total probability of one event would be 73%.  However, the events are not uncorrelated and we're over half way through 2016. I think it can be said with some confidence that it is unlikely any country will experience over 2.5% growth in 2016. Data for the first half of the year is now in and the US is closest with 2.2% forecast (IMF) however, H1 growth was 1%, so we'd need to see some upward revisions to H1 (which happens quite a lot btw) and approximately 4% growth in H2. Germany seems next most likely, but improbable, the world would need some kind of 'growth shock' in H2 and historical precedent suggests such shocks are more likely to carry downside rather than upside risk. Thus perhaps a 20% chance that the US delivers a phenomenal H2 and hits 4% and maybe a 3% chance that any other country does individually (i.e. a once in 33 year event feels about right). Inflation seems easier to hit, especially if the oil price accelerates, which it could, and the UK could also be a candidate if the currency weakness translates to inflation sooner than expected (via larger import prices) or if the rate of VAT was increased, as Japan did fairly recently. Though even here inflation was around 0.5% in H1 so a spike to roughly 4% in H2 would be needed, this would require import prices to be passed through very quickly, perhaps a 15% chance since we'd also need oil to spike or some other big shock. A similar picture is true of the other 6 countries, though without a falling currency, rising inflation seems even less probable, perhaps 3% chance. This the chance of 2.5% growth and 2% inflation NOT occurring is 0.8 for the US x 0.97^6 for everyone else x 0.85 for UK inflation and 0.97^6 for everyone else on inflation. So a 47% chance of everything NOT happening, or a 53% (1-47%) chance of the event happening. Net - this seems unlikely but it's hard to get to complete certainty given an of the 7 countries could still do something unexpected across the 2 variables in H2, but Q3 I'd expect the probability to come down pretty dramatically if things go to trend because 4% growth or inflation for 6 months is possible, but by Q4 we may need to see ~7% growth or maybe ~7% inflation in Q4 to clear the hurdle rate and that seems extremely unlikely. Where I'm really coming down on this is driven by the statistics, not so much the economics. With 14 somewhat independent events you need to have extremely high conviction, perhaps 99% that each one won't happen, for the overall probability to be low i.e. .99^14 = 0.87 or 87% chance. And at this stage in the year particularly regarding US growth and UK inflation as wildcards in H2 I don't have that much confidence, hence the idea that any single country has a small risk of surprise creates a seemingly high overall probability.

Only one of these countries has had annual GDP growth or inflation growth above 2.5% and 2% in the last 2 years. This is UK and with the expected impact from Brexit it is unlikely they'll repeat this in 2016. Still it takes only one of them to have inflation above 2% or GDP growth above 2.5% and the IMF forecast for US is just below 2.5% GDP growth. However, to get to this growth rate, the US economy has to accelerate significantly in H2 2016 after the very slow growth in H1 (1.1% in Q1 and 1.2% in Q2). Even if the Atlanta Fed's GDP Now forecast of 3.6% in Q3 is accurate, and this repeats in Q4, the annual rate won't surpass 2.5%. Also, other forecasts like the WSJ's survey of 60 economists forecast only 1.8% for 2016.

Back in April I assigned a 6% chance on the basis of the logic below. Since then, growth forecasts for the US have generally been lowered quite significantly. None of the institutions in the Bloomberg survey of c.80 economists expect US to grow at above 2.3% and consensus is well below 2.0%.  That said, Canadian inflation expectations have increased by a touch...  Overall, I'll drop this to 4% probability at this point.

France 1.2% and 0.2%
Germany 1.7% and 0.5%

US 2.0% and 1.3% Of the 79 economists in the US growth survey, 6 are estimating 2.5%, but none of the houses they represent are major US banks or investment firms. Citigroup economists are the highest major firm at 2.1%. On the balance of probabilities here, perhaps only something like a 5% chance that the US gets to this type of growth metric. In terms of Canadian inflation a single house of the 21 economists in the survey is at 2.1%. Maybe an outside chance of sub 3% that this could trigger a YES. UK growth there is one bank at 2.4% in their estimates, but not a single one of the 54 economists taking part in that number is at 2.5% or above. I'd put this at below 2%. Of course it only takes one of the 14 numbers to trigger a YES here, but it's hard to spot one that looks anything like being likely. I'm going with 6% for now.

The implied instantaneous inflation curve here http://www.bankofengland.co.uk/statistics/pages/yieldcurve/default.aspx shows inflation expectations of ~2.5% for <1 year gilts. Thus, Canada, UK and the US are the three countries that have some possibility of growth or inflation.

Predictions from various organizations are sometimes quite different from each other, and even the same organization tends to change from one report to the next. However, this question will resolve as "yes" if just one country has either inflation of 2% or more, or GDP growth of 2.5% or more i.e. out of 14 data points, Even if 13 don't make it,  the 14th would be enough. Looking at it that way, my initial 20% last month seems too low, as is the current consensus of 22%. Rough justification is given below. https://knoema.com/kyaewad/us-inflation-forecast-2015-2020-and-up-to-2060-data-and-charts
The Knoema website is very useful for a quick survey. From it, one can safely rule out Japan, Italy and France for both GDP and inflation. However,for the other four countries, the US looks the most likely for GDP growth, with the average of five predictions coming to 2.484% with a standard deviation of 0.311% (the IMF, whose report will actually decide this IFP, has the US at 2.4).   The UK is averaging 2.3% (s.d =0.27), Germany 1.88% (sd=.33) while Canada,(though averaging 2.0% with sd=0.4), looks less likely due to reduced oil output and low prices. The IMF has the UK at 1.9, Canada and Germany both at 1.5.  Without any further calculations, I'm guessing that the chance, based on these numbers, of at least one of the US or the UK reaching an average of 2.5% is better than 60% (I'm currently not in the mood to look up statistical tables beyond having found the above numbers from Excel). For inflation, Canada seems the most likely, with the average of 5 predictions at 1.77% and s.d of 0.28%.  A depreciated Canadian dollar due to low oil prices is likely to keep importing inflation. The US is a more remote possibility, averaging 1.1% (though the European Commission is an outlier, predicting 2.1%). I'd guess that there's roughly a 20% chance that Canadian inflation could exceed 2%. Thus, the chance that the averages of reports from four or five different organizations will have at least one country with GDP of 2.5% or inflation of 2.0% could be as much as 80%. However, the IMF numbers are of the order of one standard deviation less than the average, so I'll arbitrarily set my forecast at 50%. I'd appreciate it if someone more astute at statistics would comment.

I took a number of predictions available (IMF, EIU, WB, OECD, European Commission etc.) and averaged them together. It seemed, however, that historical data needed to be included in the predictions, so I did a weighted average for the GDP and Inflation growth from 2008 to 2015, with most of the weight placed on the past two years and the weight decreasing as you moved farther into the past. I then created the weighted average of  predictions to past growth (with a 2 to 1 ratio).  I then took this number and the standard deviation (again giving more weight to predictions) to create Monte Carlo simulations for each country's inflation and GDP (2000 simulations for each). if any of these simulations gave a number above the 2% Inflation increase or 2.5% GDP growth, that simulation was counted. The positive simulations were then divided by the total number of simulations conducted, which gave me a 47% chance that the criteria of this question will be met. The simulations can be updated as the various international institutions change their estimates for each country.

As mentioned elsewhere, this is the disjunction of 14 questions. For inflation: I think all 7 probabilities are close enough to zero, with perhaps the exception of Canada, that we can round even their disjunction to zero. Even Canada seems exceedingly unlikely. Furthermore, I think that more QE in any of these countries is starting to become more difficult in a geopolitical sense, even if there is no actual currency accord (http://ftalphaville.ft.com/2016/04/12/2159112/did-the-g20-agree-a-currency-accord-and-does-it-matter/).  Without the lever of monetary stimulus, I don;t see inflation topping 2% in any of these countries this year, so I'm going to round this half to 0. I also think there are more downside risks globally than upside. On GDP growth, it's worth noting that the WB has overestimated GDP growth every year since 2007, with the exception of 2010 and 2012 (http://www.un.org/esa/desa/papers/2014/wp133_2014.pdf). The OECD also had troubles with forecasting error (https://www.oecd.org/economy/oecd-forecasts-during-and-after-the-financial-crisis-a-post-mortem.htm). Though they claim to have since adjusted their methodology after learning from this. It's worth noting that the OECD Feb forecast predicts only 2% RGDP growth for the USA (https://www.oecd.org/eco/outlook/OECD-February-2016-Interim-Economic-Outlook-Forecasts-data.xlsx). Plus there's no chance of Fed assistance eg rate cuts (indeed everyone is waiting for a hike - but this requires the economy to return to health), so I think downside risks dominate here. Ultimately, this question collapses to just "will US growth be >2.5%?". Given the trend, and OECD data, and everything else, I reckon it's a 2 sigma event despite the current WB forecast being so close to 2.5 ( I think it will be revised down again), so put this at just 2%! Edit: Second thoughts, revised up - shouldn't have dismissed Canada, and too low on USA.

The only G7 country close to an expected 2016 GDP growth rate of 2.5% is the US at 2.4%, per the IMF World Economic Outlook report for April 2016 (Annex Tables 1.1.1-3), and the highest expected inflation rate among G7 countries is in Canda at 1.3%: http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2016/01/pdf/c1.pdf Thus, the only part of this question that seems relevant is the US GDP.  Knoema is a site that compiles economic projections from multiple sources (e.g. World Bank, UN, OECD): http://knoema.com/qhswwkc/us-gdp-growth-forecast-2015-2019-and-up-to-2060-data-and-charts The following sources showed US GDP growth >=2.5%: World Bank (published January 2016), UN (October 2015), European Commission (January 2016), and OECD (November 2015) Only the IMF and the Economist Intelligence Unit put the US under 2.5%, with the important caveat that the IMF's April 2016 report is by far the most current. Also more current is the meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee in March (with their April meeting finishing today), wherein only 1-2/19 members said that the US would hit 2.5% growth (figure 3.B): https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/files/fomcminutes20160316.pdf These estimates are generally pretty accurate: https://www.federalreserve.gov/econresdata/feds/2015/files/2015062pap.pdf Taking these current sources into account I think there is a low, but significant chance of breaking 2.5%, so I'll put my estimate of this at 15%, saying there are about 1.5 SD between the IMF prediction and 2.5%. Knoema also compiles Canadian inflation projections: http://knoema.com/ibldsdb/canada-inflation-forecast-2015-2019-and-up-to-2060-data-and-charts Only the OECD projects Canada over 2% CPI inflation at 2.03%, while the IMF, UN, and European Commission all place Canada's inflation rate below 2%. The Bank of Canada shows that about 45% of people surveyed on the Conference Board of Canada predict >2% inflation: http://www.bankofcanada.ca/rates/indicators/capacity-and-inflation-pressures/expectations/expectations-graph/ I'm going to put a lot of weight on the IMF's prediction here because of how current it is, and based on the fact that Canada's inflation rate in March slowed in both February and March to 1.3% in March: http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-04-22/canada-inflation-slows-for-2nd-month-on-cheaper-cars-and-gas All said, I'll put the chance at around 15%, which is a bit of a cop-out, but it sounds right. Putting them together (hi US GDP @ 15%, hi CA CPI inflation @15%), and assuming they're independent (which they aren't, but close enough), the probability of neither happening is .85^2, or 72%, so the probability of a yes to this question is 28%.

However, I think that inflation estimates are generally too low.  The reason is that oil prices were already quite low in the second half of 2015, and oil prices have been having a very negative effect on the rate of inflation over the past year.  But if oil rebounds modestly this year, then oil prices would start to have a positive effect on the rate of inflation, which would lead to temporarily high inflation in the second half of 2016.  This article outlines the general idea:
https://www.stlouisfed.org/on-the-economy/2015/october/predicting-impact-oil-prices-inflation Core CPI is already above 2% in the US, though the headline CPI only came in at 1% in the first quarter:
https://research.stlouisfed.org/fred2/graph/?g=4gir
However, this was with oil prices down 30% from the first quarter of 2015.  Oil prices averaged $58 a barrel in the second quarter last year, so it will likely still have a negative effect in the second quarter, but prices averaged $46 and $42 in the third and fourth quarters.  If oil prices rebound above $50 in the second half of the year, inflation could easily be over 2% in the U.S.  The question would then be whether it was high enough to offset inflation of around 1% in the first half of the year. I think inflation under 2% is still more likely, but both the U.S. and Canada have a chance of having higher than 2% inflation this year if oil prices rise modestly.  Overall I'll put the probability of at least one of these surprises occurring at around 50% right now, but I'll be watching GDP and oil prices.
